block.para: Here is a schematic sketch of a reflection of \RNr[n] about a hyperspace H, parallel to a vector \Vect{v} complementary to H.

info.para: In this picture, R(\Vect{x}) is the reflection of \Vect{x} about H, parallel to \Vect{v}. Similarly, R(\Vect{y}) is the reflection of \Vect{y} about H, parallel to \Vect{v}.

block.para: Here the vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} are being reflected about the hyperspace H, parallel to the vector \Vect{v}. The result of this projection are the vectors R(\Vect{x}) and R(\Vect{y}) in H, respectively. – Note that, contrary to orthogonal reflections, general reflections need not be length preserving.
